candidates.definition: Geographic regions defined by political authority, control, or territorial claims rather than natural features.

positive_examples: The disputed territory along the border remains contested by both nations.
Maritime patrols monitor the exclusive economic zone for illegal fishing.
The military established a secure perimeter around the conflict zone.
Residents organized a neighborhood watch program for their district.
Financial investigators tracked money laundering activities across the region.
Border guards inspect all vehicles crossing the international checkpoint.
negative_examples: The mountain range creates a natural barrier between the valleys.
Salmon migrate upstream through this river system every spring.
The forest ecosystem supports diverse wildlife populations.
Geologists study the volcanic activity in this geological formation.
The desert climate makes agriculture challenging in this area.
Ocean currents influence weather patterns across the Pacific basin.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: NaturalGeographicFeature, EcologicalRegion, ClimateZone, GeologicalFormation, WaterBody

candidates.definition: Geographic locations with built or designated human infrastructure for specific purposes

positive_examples: The bus stop on Fifth Avenue was crowded with commuters.
Border guards inspected passports at the checkpoint.
Vendors sold spices and textiles in the bustling marketplace.
The ancient castle attracts thousands of tourists each year.
The park became her favorite spot to read and relax.
Construction crews worked on the paved area near the building.
negative_examples: The mountain range stretched across three states.
Fish swam in the clear lake water.
Dense forest covered the hillside.
The river flowed through the valley.
Sand dunes shifted in the desert wind.
Coral reefs thrived in the tropical waters.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: NaturalLandscape, WaterBody, ClimateZone, PoliticalTerritory, EcologicalRegion

candidates.definition: Geographic areas located beneath the earth's surface or underwater.

positive_examples: The underwater canyon extends for miles along the ocean floor.
Miners discovered a vast underground cavern system beneath the mountain.
The earthquake occurred along the San Andreas fault line.
Submarine plateaus form important feeding grounds for marine life.
The tunnel runs through underground rock formations.
Coral reefs grow on submerged continental shelves.
negative_examples: The mountain peak rises above the clouds.
Coastal plains stretch inland from the shoreline.
The forest canopy blocks sunlight from reaching the ground.
Desert dunes shift with the prevailing winds.
The river valley carved through the landscape over millennia.
Grasslands cover the rolling hills of the prairie.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SurfaceTopography, AtmosphericRegion, CoastalArea, MountainousRegion, PlainArea

candidates.definition: Geographic areas formed by natural processes rather than human activity, including landforms, water bodies, and ecosystems.

positive_examples: The Amazon rainforest ecosystem spans across nine countries in South America.
The Great Lakes region contains the largest group of freshwater lakes in the world.
The Pacific Ocean covers about one-third of the Earth's surface.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.
The Rocky Mountains stretch from Canada to New Mexico.
The coral reefs of the Caribbean form a diverse marine ecosystem.
negative_examples: The state of California has a population of nearly 40 million people.
The downtown business district contains many skyscrapers.
The subway system connects all five boroughs of the city.
The agricultural zone produces wheat and corn for export.
The industrial park houses several manufacturing facilities.
The residential neighborhood has tree-lined streets and parks.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: UrbanArea, PoliticalTerritory, AdministrativeRegion, EconomicZone, CulturalRegion
